very interesting indeed. For the DOMAssert class of you-know-what-package I
ended up using the variant #2. It would be interesting to compare the different
implementations.

public class DomAssertTest extends TestCase {

private static final String XHTML_DOCTYPE = "<!DOCTYPE html PUBLIC
\"-//W3C//DTD XHTML 1.0 Strict//EN\" \"test/dtd/xhtml1-strict.dtd\">";

private boolean success;
private String expected;
private String actual;
private String message;

public DomAssertTest(boolean success, String message, String expected,
String actual) {
super("execute");

this.success = success;
this.message = message;
this.expected = expected;
this.actual = actual;
}

public static Test suite() {
TestSuite suite = new TestSuite();

suite.addTest(new DomAssertTest(true, "empty expected (long/long
forms)", "<el></el>", "<el></el>"));

// about 60 other boring tests to write....

return suite;
}

public void execute() throws Exception {
if (this.success) {
DomAssert.assertEquals(this.message,
DomUtil.asDocument(this.expected), DomUtil.asDocument(this.actual));
} else {
try {
DomAssert.assertEquals(this.message,
DomUtil.asDocument(this.expected), DomUtil.asDocument(this.actual));
} catch (AssertionFailedError expected) {
return;
}
fail();
}
}

public String getName() {
if (this.message != null) {
if (success) {
return "success " + this.message;
} else {
return "fail " + this.message;
}
} else {
return super.getName();
}
}

}
